div.p: THE LAMENTATION of the Ruling LAY-ELDERS.
Sadly bemoaning the death of their late foster-Father Sir Iohn Presbyter, deceased.
With the Resolutions both of them, and the Presbyterian Priests, in all obedience to the Parliament and people in whatsoever they shall or will command.

div.head: The Elders Lamentation, for the untimely End of Sir John Presbyter.
div.p: WHereas to the unspeakeable griefe of our hearts, wee the Lay-Elders of the City of London and Westminster have lately had just occasion to humble our selves for the untimely death of our indulgent Father Sir John Presbyter, lately deceased, since whose death we are become a scorne and reproach to all the Commons of England &c. We therefore out of a pious care of the preservation of us, our wives, and families; and as well to shelter our selves from the storme we so evidently see falling upon us, have thought fit to demonstrate to all the world our reall intentions and resolutions, as well in our own behalfes, as the behalfes of all those that have or do exercise the Presbyterian Function, whether Pastors, Deacons, or Elders &c.

1. We shall forbeare the Catechising of all that are of m • re knowledge, and better judgements then our selves, and shall send our servant or Minister to every house respectively in your Parish to give you timely notice thereof, and to invite you to the spiri • uall banquet, that we may once more unite our selves in a band of unity and concord, and be at charity amongst our slves, and so the better inabled to stand up as on man against that damnable demanding and commanding Army of Sir Thomas Fairefax.

2. We shall hereafter forbeare the frequenting of all Tavernes, Alehouses, Brothells, and the like, on the Sunday or Sabbath
dayes, and whereas we were wont to go six or seven together, wee shall hereafter visit them one by one on the working dayes, dealing with sinners by all faire meanes, and not by force or c • mpulsion drawing them and woing them to leave their lewd courses, even as two of our Predecessors woed Susanna. Th • ugh many have likened us to be Leeks, with white hoary-heads, and green tailes, not considering we are Ealdermen, that is as much as to say Eldermen, and so of more honour then Aldermen, and so without doubt derived from the word Earles, as you may re • d in Ʋerstegan: We denie our selves to be spir •• ual Elders, and shall d • ny t • joine (if y • u thinke meet) with Ecclesiasticall aff • ires, and turne Aldermen or Earles, or whatsoever you shall thinke us fitting to be: We shall also if you please be called Seniors, and G • andees of the times; but we b • seech you brethren not to terme us by the odious nick names of H • aven drivers, Dotterells, and the like; and we do hereafter pro • ise and vow in our owne names, and in the names of ou • God- ••••• rs and God-mo • hers, of the Kingdome of Scotl • n • , 〈…〉 monies that we have already taken from you, 〈…〉 and from a company of dry fellowes (that must ne • des d • inke a Sundayes) shall be imployed to these religious uses following, viz.

To build a large and spacious Stewes, accommodated with faire walkes, A • bours, and fountaines, and the like; and that there be chosen out of our severall Parishes (by us the Civill Lay-Elders) ten of the fairest yong Virgins of every Parish, or as neede requires (when ten sometimes will hardly serve one) provided they be Presbyterian, being more proper for us old men, that are become twice children, to be fu • nished with playfellowes fitting for us, then to have the rule of Churches: To which purpose, that one Elder of every Parish shall be forthwith sent to Dr. Cornelius B. who hath lately left him by will certaine Timber, and Frieze-stones, by his Father Sir John Presbyter, that he the said Dr. be desired to give, or sell at some easie rate, the said timber and stones for the pious uses aforesaid. And that the said Dr. shall have egresse and regresse through the same, both for him and his wife, or any of the rest of his venerable Brethren, and stable-roome for his Nagge: And the said
structure to be raised with all speed.

3. Being very sensible of our present condition, That we requi •• the said Ministers or servants belonging to our severall Parishes to be more moderate, and a little to forbeare their treasonous expressions against his Majesty, to rave or raile against Independents, and to blame the Parliament in some measure; in that they have lately sought their owne private interests, and not the glory of God, and good of his Church; That the great worke of Reformation hath been carryed on very coldly, very deadly, and not with that vigour and life, that so great and religious a worke requires; by which meanes we shall by degrees creepe into the aff • ctions of the people, and the better side with the dissenting Members of the House of Commons, perswading the people, that the Independents have no reall intentions towards his Majesty; but that they will proclaime him guilty of all the blood that hath lately been shed in these wars, and bring him to a tryall for the same after they have effected their owne treasonous designes; therefore let us make diligent search in all the bookes put out by the said Independents formerly against his Majesty, which will be very advantagious to our designe in hand, to make them odious to the people, and to regaine our formerly last credits, in which time we may underhand list Souldiers, and quickly get a power sufficient to resist the Army; especially considering the great influence we have over Apprentices, yong Freemen, Watermen, and the like, which we are very likely to gaine by our late petition in gathering of hands, to which end we have used our old art of specious pretentions being for the good of his Majesty, to place him and his children in their just Rights, and to maintaine the Protestant Religion, and the known Lawes of the Land—but this in private—yet we make no question but some Independent will be ready to say, that we have already divided the King from his Parliament, truct with the Scots for a Religion like themselves, and their Country, and broken all the knowne Lawes of the Land, robbed the King of the R • venue belonging to his Crowne and Dignity, divorst him from his Wife, and deare Children, prosecuted a most horrid and bloody Rebellion that ever was knowne to be in any Nation; robbed
him of the hearts of his Subjects, hanged and butchered many of his loyall Subjects, kept him their prisoner, and plundered free Denizens and Subjects only for maintaining their Oath of Allegiance to his Majesty, according to their bounded duty; and all this acted quite contrary to the knowne Lawes of the Land, and the actors as lyable to receive punish • ent for all this, as any thiefe that ever suffered at Tybu • ne. N • y, they will not stick to tell us, we have not on • y done all this, but we have sought to make all our owne, whilst we have brought our selves to the Proverb, All covet, all lose.

Alas poore Independents, this you m • y pretend, and lay to the charge of us innocent Presbyters, that have no more harme in us then a Devill of ten yeares old, though we are hardly christened or knowne by our names in this Kingdome; yet we are become more odious in this our infancy, then ever the Bishops were in old age: We were fully contented with their places, and fat Benefices, and would have been very well content to have kept their wives with the sweat of our bodies, on condition if we might enjoy them quickly: And truely brethren our Ministers should have choaked the people with dusting the cushion in their spirituall pangs, till wee were (by the helpe of a Scotch Midwife) delivered of so dreadfull aA child like the Father, or the true character of a Presbyter. Monster, that all her Majesties Beares could never lick into any forme: In his mouth were to be seen blasphemies, treasons, tautologies, and the like, under his forked tongue was the poyson of Aspes, raylings, and cursed speeches, his face was like the face of a Presbyter, in his clawes was a bloody devouring sword, his feete were swift to shed innocent blood, from him proceeded rebellions, pride, lust, sacriledge, and the like; with such an abominable abundance of impieties never before thought of. This Monster was borne in nasty Scotland, wrapt up in an old cloakbagge, and sent to Westminster to nruse, and in the space of 4 yeeres, is become so untoward a Chit, that to give you his true character, or draw him forth to the life, would adde blacknesse to my inke, and palenesse to my paper, and infuse a kinde of trembling palsie into my fainting hand, that I should be forced abruptly to breake off, and write only Finis, &c.

div.head: The Priests resolution, and motion to the People.
div.p:
WEe shall in the next place demonstrate our obedience unto the Parliament and people, stedfastly purposing to turne over a new leafe, and learne a new lesson: and to side with what Religion soever the State shall thinke fit: If you will have us be Anabaptists, Brownists, or the like, we good honest minded Priests, shall be content, so you will but let us still enjoy our fat Benefices, and confirme on us the Bishops Lands, and the holy Ordinance for Tithes, wee shall in all obedience conforme to any thing you will have us. I • you desire to have the Service Booke read againe in your Churches, you shall have it: if the Directory, 'tis all one to us: if you will hav • Altars again, Crosses and cringing, with holy water, Auricular Confession, Penance, Altar-worship, and Saint-worship too, we shall bee content, so it contents you: and truly (if you shall thinke it fitting) we shall be content that there be some harmlesse Recreations allowed the Youth both of the City and Country, on the Sabbath or Lords day; as Dancing, Bowling, Drinking, Drabbing, or the like, it may prove a great incouragement to the yong men, and will make them the willinger to perform their labours on the working dayes. And whereas we have formerly altered our Religions, even as the Prince, or the times required; as in the reigne of King Henry the Eight, when hee was a Papist, we (good men) made no scruple to be Papists; when hee turnd Protestant, we turnd Protestants too: then in the reigne of Queene Mary presently after, we turnd Papists againe: then Protestants againe in Queene Elizabeths Reigne; and so wee shall still turne to whatsoever you will have us, so you will not turne us out of our goodly fat Benefices, that were an ill turne indeed, to expose us to The good will of the vulgar; that vexes us to the guts, and makes our very bowels to earne: Oh the heavenly consideration of the blessed tithe pigs, capons, geese, &c. O let s but quietly enjoy our livings, and tithes, and wee shall give you all cause to rejoice, from the highest to the lowest, from the King to the beggar, then we shall be as free from fear as from honesty: then we shall have a brave world for them that
shall live in't; you shall have free exercise of your Religion in houses, or any where else: you shall not be nick-named, Anabaptists, Brownists, Antinomians, and the like; you shall have the ancient Holy dayes observed, Crosses restored to their golden glory (and by the leave of Dr. Burges) Pauls shall once mor • recover his ancient Organ-pipes, Saints-dayes; Feasts, and Wakes shall be againe solemnized, by the friendly assistance of Fidlers, Players, Juglers, May-poles, and Morrice-dances; if this New Reformation will please you, it will assuredly please us; this will questionlesse produce a peace to some purpose; then farewell feares, farewell jealousies, farewell plots, farewel • petition • , and gathering of hands, all things that you can wish shalbe g anted, without asking. What thinke you of this Independents? will it not be a happy age? will you not fling downe your Armes for joy, and side with us now? we are your kindred, your friends and neighbours; wee can allow you to have the placing of the King in his Throne, be the restorers of the Kingdomes Lawes, and regainers of your lately lost Liberties, release your Prisoners, choose a new Parliament, and have the freedome of the Gospell: We beseech you to accept of the honour whilest it is offered you: if ye will not listen unto us, we purpose to continue our old trades still, in renewing and prosecuting dissentions, of raysing a bloudy war, till we (like the tyrant Nero) have ript up the tender bowels of our dear Mother, our Native Country, and make no conscience to fight against our owne lawfull King, the anointed of the Lord, and against our owne Lawes, and dearly purchased Liberties, though wee become even the prodigy of the times, and the shame of all Nations.

div.head: Postscript.
div.p: MOst wicked Elders, and Presbyterian Priests, if you persist in your desperate designes to renew a second war, where will you hereafter bestow your selves while ye live, and whether will ye go when ye die? What Countrey will entertaine you? What people will trust you? Heaven doubtlesse will exclude you? And Hell be too hot for you: Therefore blush for shame ye Bastards of England (for legittimate children ye cannot be) that prosecute such horrid actions, and hatch such Crocadiles egges of Rebellion and murther, that the very Infidells, Pagans, Turkes, Saracens, and no Nation (thoagh never so barbarous and cruel) but would shame to owne. Though ye feare not man, yet you ought to feare God, whose al-seeing eye beholds your closest plots, and contrivances, and will undoubtedly repay vengeance to all the enemies of peace and truth, Vale.
div.closer: God save King Charles, and Sir Thomas Fairefax, and preserve this Nation.

div.head: The Elders Lamentation.
div.l: I Cannot chuse but laugh at your distresse,
And joyfull be at your great heavinesse.
Since you such paines have tane in making way
To others ruines, now see your owne decay:
You roote and branch did pull the Bishops up,
And now your selves must drink of the same cup.
You'd best complaine toth' King, and let him know,
That you want truth, and justice here below,
Make him to know your wants, perhap; that he
May prescribe you hempe, to ease your misery.
The only way I know to make you well,
And send you to your Father Jack in hell

l.hi: Is to let all the people say Amen.
